<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Felectric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas%2Four%20insights%2Ffive%20trends%20that%20are%20reshaping%20european%20power%20markets%2Ffive-trends-reshaping-european-power-markets.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="five-trends-reshaping-european-power-markets" data-layer-report-name="five-trends-reshaping-european-power-markets>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (8 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div> <!-- -->
<p><strong>European power markets</strong> have entered a period of unprecedented change. Power prices have touched new highs: baseload week-ahead prices have risen above €200 per megawatt-hour (MWh)<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bf27707f-4c68-40ff-97b3-02016ba6ee26"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bf27707f-4c68-40ff-97b3-02016ba6ee26" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Platts European Power Daily, S&P Global, spglobal.com.</span></span></span></a></span> in a number of European countries—about four times the average historical level. That increase has been prompted largely by a surge in natural-gas and carbon prices, which currently exceed €100 per MWh<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ac618c7e-175a-49c5-8b3f-c4546e4a42fe"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ac618c7e-175a-49c5-8b3f-c4546e4a42fe" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">TTF (Title Transfer Facility).</span></span></span></a></span> and €60 per metric ton, respectively. This development has affected the cost of power produced by natural-gas power plants, which broadly set prices in European markets.</p>
<p>At the same time, price volatility is reaching new heights as a result of the uncertain output of renewable assets and a tight supply-and-demand balance in the European power system. Navigating this next normal will be a key challenge for utilities, traders, and large power consumers, and that highlights the importance of developing resilient power-asset portfolios and managing risk. </p>
<p>In this article, we explore five trends that will shape the European power sector in the decade to come and offer some perspectives on how utilities and large consumers might respond.</p>
<h2>What’s ahead for the European power sector?</h2>
<p>The European power market is undergoing major changes. Five trends underpin these developments. </p>
<h3>Sustained growth in power demand, supported by climate-related targets </h3>
<p>Electricity demand is expected to increase steadily in Europe, at a CAGR of about 2 percent until 2035. The main factors behind the surge will be the electrification of transport and a ramp-up in the production of green hydrogen through electrolysis, requiring renewable power (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/five%20trends%20that%20are%20reshaping%20european%20power%20markets/svgz-eu-marketperspectives-v12-cs-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Europe is expected to experience sustained growth in power demand  through 2035." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/five%20trends%20that%20are%20reshaping%20european%20power%20markets/svgz-eu-marketperspectives-v12-cs-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Transport power demand will grow by 14 percent CAGR as a result of the rollout of the electrification infrastructure and national regulations on emissions (for example, if cities ban internal-combustion engines and impose fiscal measures to discourage the use of nonelectric vehicles). The power requirements of green-hydrogen production will expand by about 40 percent CAGR, absorbing 230 terawatt-hours (TWh) of renewables output by 2035 across Europe—the equivalent of nearly a third of Germany’s total consumption. Demand will grow only modestly in the industrial, commercial, and residential sectors because efficiency measures will mostly offset the electrification of industrial processes and residential equipment. </p>
<h3>A future energy system dominated by intermittent production, with uncertainty about total capacity rollout </h3>
<p>The expectation is that more than 650 gigawatts (GW) of intermittent renewable power, including wind and solar, will be developed from 2021 to 2035. Intermittent renewables will account for about 60 percent of total installed capacity in Europe in 2035, compared with about 35 percent in 2021 (Exhibit 2). However, it remains uncertain whether the pace at which renewables are rolled out will be sufficient: </p>
<ul>
    <li>Project permissions have been delayed in a number of European countries. As a result, the gap between the time projects are proposed and commissioned is up to seven years.</li>
    <li>The modernization of the grid faces significant challenges as the production of renewable power drives nodal imbalances, requiring utilities to invest in new transmission and distribution assets.</li>
    <li>Restrictions have been placed on the development of renewables assets in a growing number of countries—for example, limitations on onshore wind development as a result of concerns about biodiversity or noise and visual pollution. </li>
</ul>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/five%20trends%20that%20are%20reshaping%20european%20power%20markets/svgz-eu-marketperspectives-v12-cs-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Intermittent production will dominate the European power sector." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/five%20trends%20that%20are%20reshaping%20european%20power%20markets/svgz-eu-marketperspectives-v12-cs-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h3>The phaseout of coal and nuclear assets</h3>
<p>A large drop in dispatchable, or controllable, generation assets is expected because the use of coal is being phased out and nuclear plants are being decommissioned. This issue highlights the power system’s reliance on weather-dependent renewables and on natural gas. Adverse wind and solar conditions or a slower pace of development for renewables could lead to power shortages. Gas prices may also fluctuate more, given the demand sensitivity of heating and the need for dispatchable power generation. In particular, European coal and lignite capacity will drop drastically—by about 70 percent from 2021 to 2035. Western and Northern European countries are taking the lead in these cutbacks.</p>
<p>Meanwhile, a number of EU countries are not renewing their existing nuclear-power assets and are making few new investments. Nuclear capacity is expected to decline by 23 percent from 2021 to 2035 (Exhibit 3). Germany, Belgium, and Spain have announced that they will close all their nuclear plants by 2022, 2025, and 2035, respectively. France has started closing its oldest nuclear plant while building a 1,650-MW new-generation reactor. The United Kingdom is developing a new 3,200-MW nuclear project, though delays and costs may hinder the further development of nuclear capacity there.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/five%20trends%20that%20are%20reshaping%20european%20power%20markets/svgz-eu-marketperspectives-v12-cs-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="A large drop in dispatchable generation assets is expected in Europe, caused by phaseouts of coal use and the decommissioning of nuclear plants." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/five%20trends%20that%20are%20reshaping%20european%20power%20markets/svgz-eu-marketperspectives-v12-cs-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h3>The critical role of gas and batteries to bridge dispatchable-power capacity needs </h3>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-right-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>To ensure the grid’s stability, the power sector must compensate for the drop in dispatchable assets.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>To ensure the grid’s stability, the power sector must compensate for the drop in dispatchable assets. We expect new ones, such as natural-gas power plants and batteries, to partly balance the grid as coal and nuclear generation decline. More than 14 GW of natural gas are expected to come on line, mostly from 2021 to 2030, and more than 80 GW in batteries, primarily from 2030 to 2035. Yet a number of investments are contingent on national capacity mechanisms to avoid the risks of stranded assets for investors. Capacity mechanisms will also depend on compatibility with EU regulations and the EU’s Fit for 55 package. Overall, natural gas is expected to remain a critical source of dispatchable power, especially in periods with prolonged low renewables output.</p>
<p>Declining battery-storage costs may encourage the rollout of batteries to alleviate the shortfall in dispatchable capacity. But the pace may be slower than anticipated, since European countries have not kick-started the industry with storage mandates like those in some US states. Still, doubts remain about the potential for cost reductions. The uncertainties include recent inflation in the cost of battery materials and questions about the pace of the rollout of “giga-factories” for grid-scale batteries. </p>
<h3>The rise of an integrated European power market with Germany at its core</h3>
<p>We expect a more integrated European power market including significant coupling of power hubs. With cross-border flows of about 200 TWh a year in 2030, Germany is expected to be at the center of the European power system. The country, now a net power exporter, is expected to become a net power importer by the mid 2020s. Interconnection capacity could grow about 50 percent by 2030 (Exhibits 4 and 5), and this should further reinforce Germany’s position as Europe’s most liquid power market. The country represents a key strategic region for European utilities and traders aiming to manage market risks in their power portfolios. </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/five%20trends%20that%20are%20reshaping%20european%20power%20markets/svgz-eu-marketperspectives-v12-cs-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Germany is expected to increasingly rely on imports." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/five%20trends%20that%20are%20reshaping%20european%20power%20markets/svgz-eu-marketperspectives-v12-cs-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h2>Implications for the European power system </h2>
<p>Fundamental trends in the European power system are expected to lead to a much more volatile power-pricing environment, as we already see from this year’s power-price surge. Europe is entering a period of extreme volatility, with daily and hourly prices hitting new highs. In Germany, upward of 3,000 hours a year may be priced at more than €100 or at less than €10 by 2030, compared with just several hundred hours today, according to McKinsey’s EU Power Model. This volatility could spur new behavior from market participants—for example, the level at which they bid for their electricity supplies or hedge their future needs.</p>
<p>One way for players to better understand the power market’s dynamics, including volatility, is the merit-order cost curve, which illustrates the price-setting mechanism in the power market. Five elements are particularly important to anticipate future movement in power prices and price volatility (Exhibit 6): </p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Gas, coal, and CO₂ prices altering the marginal production costs of thermal power plants. </em>The rise or fall of gas, coal, and CO₂ prices will drive the volatility of the market’s clearing price. </li>
    <li><em>The intermittency of renewables. </em>The volume of renewables power output will push the curve either to the left or to the right, potentially leading to very low or very high clearing prices. </li>
    <li><em>Dispatchable-asset new builds. </em>Uncertainty about the volume and cost of dispatchable-asset new builds (for example, batteries and combined-cycle gas turbines) could raise or lower clearing prices. </li>
    <li><em>Average load uncertainty. </em>Volatility in hourly power demand from sources such as electric-vehicle charging and industrial electrification could create supply shortages leading to high clearing prices during certain hours. </li>
    <li><em>Strategic bids during shortages.</em> In a growing number of hours, anticipated supply shortages could lead market players to bid their capacity at prices higher than the marginal cost, theoretically up to the maximum allowed price. </li>
</ul>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 6</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/five%20trends%20that%20are%20reshaping%20european%20power%20markets/svgz-eu-marketperspectives-v12-cs-ex6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The merit-order cost curve exemplifies the pricing mechanism in the European power market." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/five%20trends%20that%20are%20reshaping%20european%20power%20markets/svgz-eu-marketperspectives-v12-cs-ex6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h2>How can market players respond?</h2>
<p>The European power market is entering uncharted territory. When utilities and large power buyers face that kind of uncertainty, strategic risk management becomes a matter of survival. In the United Kingdom, recent defaults of power and gas retailers, following the surge in gas prices, illustrate the high stakes. Here are some steps players can take to address the uncertainties:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Investing in best-in-class risk-management models.</em> These would cover market-price risks along with the nonlinear volume or shape risks of day-ahead and intraday power markets. For example, players could make more use of advanced stochastic profit-at-risk or cash-flow-at-risk models, such as running them in quasi-real time to best inform hedging strategies. Ad-hoc stress tests will also be critical to run on a periodic basis. </li>
    <li><em>Pursuing flexibility in portfolios. </em>To reduce exposure to price surges in wholesale
    power markets, players could source more flexibility both on the demand and supply
    sides of portfolios, including, for example, demand-side response aggregation and investments in gas-peaker assets, grid-scale batteries, and virtual power plants (VPP).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="429baae9-e42c-4453-a906-133a2b3ecf51"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="429baae9-e42c-4453-a906-133a2b3ecf51" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">VPPs can provide the flexibility of a traditional power plant. They are executed through a financial agreement between parties.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Developing an active presence in the most liquid European power hubs. </em>Germany is expected to remain the most liquid market and an ideal place to optimize hedging strategies across Europe—for example, by employing proxy hedges and cross-border hedges in the event
    of strong market coupling and limited liquidity in other markets. </li>
    <li><em>Using power purchase agreements with partial or full fixed-price arrangements. </em>Companies could use this strategy to hedge long-term power purchases or sales, thus reducing exposures to volatile power prices.</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p>The European power market is entering an unprecedented phase. Market participants that hope to be industry leaders must urgently invest in best-in-class risk and portfolio management.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div 5]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEuropean power markets\u003c/strong\u003e have entered a period of unprecedented change. Power prices have touched new highs: baseload week-ahead prices have risen above \u0026euro;200 per megawatt-hour (MWh)[[Footnote 1]] in a number of European countries\u0026mdash;about four times the average historical level. That increase has been prompted largely by a surge in natural-gas and carbon prices, which currently exceed \u0026euro;100 per MWh[[Footnote 2]] and \u0026euro;60 per metric ton, respectively. This development has affected the cost of power produced by natural-gas power plants, which broadly set prices in European markets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt the same time, price volatility is reaching new heights as a result of the uncertain output of renewable assets and a tight supply-and-demand balance in the European power system. Navigating this next normal will be a key challenge for utilities, traders, and large power consumers, and that highlights the importance of developing resilient power-asset portfolios and managing risk. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this article, we explore five trends that will shape the European power sector in the decade to come and offer some perspectives on how utilities and large consumers might respond.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhat\u0026rsquo;s ahead for the European power sector?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe European power market is undergoing major changes. Five trends underpin these developments. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSustained growth in power demand, supported by climate-related targets \u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eElectricity demand is expected to increase steadily in Europe, at a CAGR of about 2 percent until 2035. The main factors behind the surge will be the electrification of transport and a ramp-up in the production of green hydrogen through electrolysis, requiring renewable power (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eTransport power demand will grow by 14 percent CAGR as a result of the rollout of the electrification infrastructure and national regulations on emissions (for example, if cities ban internal-combustion engines and impose fiscal measures to discourage the use of nonelectric vehicles). The power requirements of green-hydrogen production will expand by about 40 percent CAGR, absorbing 230 terawatt-hours (TWh) of renewables output by 2035 across Europe\u0026mdash;the equivalent of nearly a third of Germany\u0026rsquo;s total consumption. Demand will grow only modestly in the industrial, commercial, and residential sectors because efficiency measures will mostly offset the electrification of industrial processes and residential equipment. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eA future energy system dominated by intermittent production, with uncertainty about total capacity rollout \u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe expectation is that more than 650 gigawatts (GW) of intermittent renewable power, including wind and solar, will be developed from 2021 to 2035. Intermittent renewables will account for about 60 percent of total installed capacity in Europe in 2035, compared with about 35 percent in 2021 (Exhibit 2). However, it remains uncertain whether the pace at which renewables are rolled out will be sufficient: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eProject permissions have been delayed in a number of European countries. As a result, the gap between the time projects are proposed and commissioned is up to seven years.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe modernization of the grid faces significant challenges as the production of renewable power drives nodal imbalances, requiring utilities to invest in new transmission and distribution assets.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eRestrictions have been placed on the development of renewables assets in a growing number of countries\u0026mdash;for example, limitations on onshore wind development as a result of concerns about biodiversity or noise and visual pollution. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003ch3\u003eThe phaseout of coal and nuclear assets\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA large drop in dispatchable, or controllable, generation assets is expected because the use of coal is being phased out and nuclear plants are being decommissioned. This issue highlights the power system\u0026rsquo;s reliance on weather-dependent renewables and on natural gas. Adverse wind and solar conditions or a slower pace of development for renewables could lead to power shortages. Gas prices may also fluctuate more, given the demand sensitivity of heating and the need for dispatchable power generation. In particular, European coal and lignite capacity will drop drastically\u0026mdash;by about 70 percent from 2021 to 2035. Western and Northern European countries are taking the lead in these cutbacks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMeanwhile, a number of EU countries are not renewing their existing nuclear-power assets and are making few new investments. Nuclear capacity is expected to decline by 23 percent from 2021 to 2035 (Exhibit 3). Germany, Belgium, and Spain have announced that they will close all their nuclear plants by 2022, 2025, and 2035, respectively. France has started closing its oldest nuclear plant while building a 1,650-MW new-generation reactor. The United Kingdom is developing a new 3,200-MW nuclear project, though delays and costs may hinder the further development of nuclear capacity there.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003ch3\u003eThe critical role of gas and batteries to bridge dispatchable-power capacity needs \u003c/h3\u003e\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eTo ensure the grid\u0026rsquo;s stability, the power sector must compensate for the drop in dispatchable assets. We expect new ones, such as natural-gas power plants and batteries, to partly balance the grid as coal and nuclear generation decline. More than 14 GW of natural gas are expected to come on line, mostly from 2021 to 2030, and more than 80 GW in batteries, primarily from 2030 to 2035. Yet a number of investments are contingent on national capacity mechanisms to avoid the risks of stranded assets for investors. Capacity mechanisms will also depend on compatibility with EU regulations and the EU\u0026rsquo;s Fit for 55 package. Overall, natural gas is expected to remain a critical source of dispatchable power, especially in periods with prolonged low renewables output.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDeclining battery-storage costs may encourage the rollout of batteries to alleviate the shortfall in dispatchable capacity. But the pace may be slower than anticipated, since European countries have not kick-started the industry with storage mandates like those in some US states. Still, doubts remain about the potential for cost reductions. The uncertainties include recent inflation in the cost of battery materials and questions about the pace of the rollout of \u0026ldquo;giga-factories\u0026rdquo; for grid-scale batteries. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe rise of an integrated European power market with Germany at its core\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe expect a more integrated European power market including significant coupling of power hubs. With cross-border flows of about 200 TWh a year in 2030, Germany is expected to be at the center of the European power system. The country, now a net power exporter, is expected to become a net power importer by the mid 2020s. Interconnection capacity could grow about 50 percent by 2030 (Exhibits 4 and 5), and this should further reinforce Germany\u0026rsquo;s position as Europe\u0026rsquo;s most liquid power market. The country represents a key strategic region for European utilities and traders aiming to manage market risks in their power portfolios. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n[[Exhibit 5]]\n\u003ch2\u003eImplications for the European power system \u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFundamental trends in the European power system are expected to lead to a much more volatile power-pricing environment, as we already see from this year\u0026rsquo;s power-price surge. Europe is entering a period of extreme volatility, with daily and hourly prices hitting new highs. In Germany, upward of 3,000 hours a year may be priced at more than \u0026euro;100 or at less than \u0026euro;10 by 2030, compared with just several hundred hours today, according to McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s EU Power Model. This volatility could spur new behavior from market participants\u0026mdash;for example, the level at which they bid for their electricity supplies or hedge their future needs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne way for players to better understand the power market\u0026rsquo;s dynamics, including volatility, is the merit-order cost curve, which illustrates the price-setting mechanism in the power market. Five elements are particularly important to anticipate future movement in power prices and price volatility (Exhibit 6): \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eGas, coal, and CO₂ prices altering the marginal production costs of thermal power plants. \u003c/em\u003eThe rise or fall of gas, coal, and CO₂ prices will drive the volatility of the market\u0026rsquo;s clearing price. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe intermittency of renewables. \u003c/em\u003eThe volume of renewables power output will push the curve either to the left or to the right, potentially leading to very low or very high clearing prices. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDispatchable-asset new builds. \u003c/em\u003eUncertainty about the volume and cost of dispatchable-asset new builds (for example, batteries and combined-cycle gas turbines) could raise or lower clearing prices. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAverage load uncertainty. \u003c/em\u003eVolatility in hourly power demand from sources such as electric-vehicle charging and industrial electrification could create supply shortages leading to high clearing prices during certain hours. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eStrategic bids during shortages.\u003c/em\u003e In a growing number of hours, anticipated supply shortages could lead market players to bid their capacity at prices higher than the marginal cost, theoretically up to the maximum allowed price. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[Exhibit 6]]\n\u003ch2\u003eHow can market players respond?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe European power market is entering uncharted territory. When utilities and large power buyers face that kind of uncertainty, strategic risk management becomes a matter of survival. In the United Kingdom, recent defaults of power and gas retailers, following the surge in gas prices, illustrate the high stakes. Here are some steps players can take to address the uncertainties:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eInvesting in best-in-class risk-management models.\u003c/em\u003e These would cover market-price risks along with the nonlinear volume or shape risks of day-ahead and intraday power markets. For example, players could make more use of advanced stochastic profit-at-risk or cash-flow-at-risk models, such as running them in quasi-real time to best inform hedging strategies. Ad-hoc stress tests will also be critical to run on a periodic basis. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePursuing flexibility in portfolios. \u003c/em\u003eTo reduce exposure to price surges in wholesale\n    power markets, players could source more flexibility both on the demand and supply\n    sides of portfolios, including, for example, demand-side response aggregation and investments in gas-peaker assets, grid-scale batteries, and virtual power plants (VPP).[[Footnote 3]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDeveloping an active presence in the most liquid European power hubs. \u003c/em\u003eGermany is expected to remain the most liquid market and an ideal place to optimize hedging strategies across Europe\u0026mdash;for example, by employing proxy hedges and cross-border hedges in the event\n    of strong market coupling and limited liquidity in other markets. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eUsing power purchase agreements with partial or full fixed-price arrangements. \u003c/em\u003eCompanies could use this strategy to hedge long-term power purchases or sales, thus reducing exposures to volatile power prices.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe European power market is entering an unprecedented phase. Market participants that hope to be industry leaders must urgently invest in best-in-class risk and portfolio management.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-10-19T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ePlatts European Power Daily, S\u0026amp;P Global, spglobal.com.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eTTF (Title Transfer Facility).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eVPPs can provide the flexibility of a traditional power plant.
